column1: In California v. Texas, will the Supreme Court rule that reducing the penalty amount for the individual mandate of the Affordable Care Act (ACA) to zero rendered the individual mandate provision unconstitutional?
column6: ['Business', 'Health', 'US Politics', 'US Policy']
https://www.businessinsider.com/supreme-court-upholds-affordable-care-act-california-v-texas-2021-6
Looks like this will resolve negatively, -20
https://www.supremecourt.gov/opinions/20pdf/19-840_6jfm.pdf

SCOTUS will be unenthusiastic I believe in dismantling the ACA, both due to resulting chaos in health care but also prior ACA ruling by Roberts would be undone. There is some chance they will rule plaintiffs do not have standing and will perhaps view this as a political problem to be solved by Congress not in a lawsuit between states.
Passage of time.
Post-mortem update: I did rather well at predicting Kavanaugh and Roberts would join the said others in the majority opinion, but I did not get the correct side of the question.

Well, the crowd was unreasonable about Google v. Oracle; is it as unreasonable about ACA?
Seems unlikely.
This has already been argued and decided on by the Supreme Court. Therefore, will the Court even decide on it? Probably not.

The Gov't flip sides and now supprts the position that 1) the tax/penalty is constitutional and 2) if tax/penaty is found unconstitutional then it can be severed from ACA and remaining provisions are enforceable. This GJ question is only about the tax/penalty and not striking down the entire ACA. Yes, i still believe tax/penalty will be found unconstitutional. (Going to be one hell of a brier hit :) +/-)
I actually think there is a decent chance this question will resolve yes, but my previous prediction was much higher so I am compensating.
When is this happening, anyone have an idea?
Looks likely to stand Thank God.

Two justices, Alito and Thomas, have already demonstrated their hostility to the ACA, but the Chief Justice remains convinced it was constitutional. In bills as big as this one, the judges tend to knock down only those parts they feel they must. I just find it hard to believe Gorsuch would go there. It honestly feels like this could be a 6-3 decision, but it might be 5-4. We'll see.
Down 15%. Suspect the SCOTUS will do anything to not get materially involved. â€”especially since the Biden may appeal to withdraw from the whole thing.
(no change) Will likely move off the consensus after the oral arguments today (and the NY decision).
There seems to be a majority that have voiced deep skepticism.
Following the crowd a bit.
Down 15% but never underestimate stupidity.
Looks like severability wins this one.
Before taking into account the current aggregate, I'm at 55%. Afterwards, 40%.

-10 after listening to oral arguments. I don't know how they would decide on the mandate. I personally think the argument against its constitutionality is very unconvincing. If it was legal as a tax, the idea that lowering the penalty to zero makes it more coercive and more of a command and that it's unconstitutional because it no longer raises revenue and therefore can't be considered a tax seems absurd. But court conservatives could be more open to that argument than me, though there did seem to be some skepticism in the questioning. But my main reason for dropping the likelihood is because most of the questions focused on standing and much less on the other issues. So I think there's a good chance the other questions aren't reached because the court rules the plaintiffs don't have standing.

Here's 2 commentaries suggesting that; - the justices will vote to 5-4 or 6-3 in rejecting the severability argument, - the lack of punishment does not nullify the validity of a command (to close in on lay terms), and - Texas may lack the standing to bring this case to the Court.
Down 10% after reading a bit more about the questioning. Could still be socratic.

Four ways this can go: - Denying standing - Holding that the residual mandate is not unconstitutional - Striking down the mandate while simultaneously ruling that it is severable from the rest of the law - Striking down the mandate & ruling that it is not severable.

It is assumed that judges John Roberts and Brett Kavanaugh lean toward a separation of the individual mandate provision from the remainder of "Obamacare" in order to preserve the ACA even if one single aspect of it should fall.

They heard oral arguments today. many of the comments in court seemed to imply that they are leaning towards severability which would imply that they are going to rule it unconstitutional. You don't need to sever it unless it's unconstitutional.

Going back to 90% because i think the republicans hold the senate 80%. This means my concern about a democratic controlled congress in 2021reestablishing the $700 penalty and rendering this case smooth is reduced. Also based on today's arguments at the Supreme Court as reported by the Hil it seems to conservative justices would vote to sever penalty from ACA without invalidating the ACA. I also think that even if the Dems do take Congress that they would not want to waste the time to re-establish the penalty in lieu of correcting the legislative flaws in the ACA. No I would not be surprised if on January 4th I come back in the update this forecast for the election.

Up 10%. Most experts I trust think that the ACA should be tweaked a bit (and perhaps keep brain dead states from not expanding something like Medicaid). If there were quiet discussions with adults in the room that might have connections to SCOTUS (of course it shouldn't be influenced according to simple govt theory), then striking it down (on whatever lame reasons they used) as part of a plan to update the ACA with bipartisan Congressional action. For all I care it can be called "TrumpCare" since it was envisioned in the EO's.

I really believe the answer is yes. But the election has raised the possibility of a moot outcome. Assuming Biden wins and Dems hold the house, and senate is tied the Congress can restablish the monetary penalty before the Court issues an opinion thereby rendering the controversy moot and removing the need for the opinion. When moot is available Scotju always chooses moot. So 67% comes off.
severarable.
(no change) Everyone "knows" SCOTUS prefers to be apolitical, but results of Presidential and Congressional election would be lurking in the background before any decision.
If Amy Barret wants to keep her majority-and if/ or Roberts the mandate is severable clearly She invalidates act I'm wrong Hope Roberts gets her straightened out No difference Dems add 4 more

page 13. of https://scholar.princeton.edu/sites/default/files/benjohnson/files/why_does_the_supreme_court_uphold_so_many_laws.pdf suggests that the SCOTUS upholds laws more often than not. Going down.
Reducing simply due to liklihood of SCOTUS avoiding and not ruling on this particular issue, since it is not the main issue.
Deference to the aggregate
This seems to be all about severability. Nobody much seems to doubt that the principle applies in this case. On the other hand, life is strange.
This has changed since the death of RBG. Now it is likely to fall.

My last forecast erred. Need to account for Roberts allowing the mandate to be unconstitutional while allowing the rest of the law to stand with severability. So, here the question is whether a tax is still a tax even if the rate is currently set at O. Here, a potentially new set of people in Congress might set the tax at something small north of 0 which would make the case moot.

The nut of the case: the mandate is no longer a tax because Congress changed its tax to zero. And because the tax is currently set at zero, plaintiffs assert that the entire law is therefore unconstitutional, hence the entire ACA should be struck down. Roberts already voted twice in support of the ACA. Hearing set to hear arguments on November 10. RBG's replacement is more likely to support striking down the law in its entirety. However, one cannot assume that Roberts doesn't convince at least one other Justice to vote with him on severability, possibly Kavanaugh and/or Alito. Slate: https://slate.com/news-and-politics/2020/09/saving-obamacare-supreme-court-case.html
(no change) In addition to the noted question I believe there is a related issue of "severabiity." This may be important in forecasting.

Up 20% to be at the consensus. With the HHS $300M "Operation Warp Mind" (made up), EO's that have solved all, and GOP blather related to the US healthcare realities, sane policy choices have left the room. â€”which means I suspect the SCOTUS may perceive that some construct fits the perceived reality. â€”though I'd bet JR would really rather not go there (CU and BvG have been damaging enough to their claim to wise decisions). YMMV
Going up another 5%

-35. The more I think about this and the more I read the less likely it seems that the mandate will be ruled unconstitutional. It seems very plausible that the new justices hold with precedent and say the changes aren't enough to overturn the previous case ruling the mandate a tax and therefore constitutional. And it seems like the question of standing may be weak as well, which I believe would leave the rest untouched.

-15, backing off on this a little. My updated reasoning was based on the idea that it would be a 4-4 split thereby upholding the circuit decision on a tie. But there are two new conservative justices since the last decision on the mandate, Kavanaugh and Gorsuch. It's possible that one of them could side with Roberts' view that the mandate can be considered a tax and be constitutional. Or one of them could hold to precedent from the previous Roberts decision and join the majority in saying the new facts aren't substantial enough to change the previous decision. But I'll still lean toward the possibility of a tie and upholding the circuit decision. And there's always the possibility that the new facts actually do change Roberts' mind, or that a new justice is confirmed in time for the case which could change things up.

Increasing due to the SCOTUS vacancy creating a higher likelihood that a more Conservative court could support making the ACA unconstitutional based on the mandate being 0. This forecast is based on the presumption that at least 50 Republican Senators will support a Trump nominee either in the lame duck session or before the election.

+70 on the death of RBG. In the event of a tie the court affirms the judgement of the lower court. The original decision would now be a tie with RBG gone and I expected them to split along the same lines in this case. Keeping it a little uncertain at 80 because there's still the question of timing that I don't know much about.
So annoyed with myself. Thought this was another question and now I've gone in on something I had no idea about.
Going up by 10% because RGB is dead and her replacement probably more conservative. Going down 5% because her death might delay this resolution.
Lowering my prediction based on earlier comments

Roberts wrote the ACA majority decision. Roberts found that the penalty had the characteristics of a tax. The circuit court latches on to one line in Roberts' opinion: "This process yields the essential feature of any tax: it produces at least some revenue for the Government." Using that line they argue that a penalty of $0 no longer satisfies that component and therefore it's no longer a tax and is unconstitutional.
Worth noting: https://lawandcrime.com/supreme-court/justice-kavanaugh-may-have-tipped-the-scotuss-hand-on-obamacare-decision-through-a-robocall-case/
This seems unlikely, at least prior to the election. After the election, I feel like the odds might rise, particularly if Biden wins.
It was a bad law to start with. the SC has a conservative bent now
it can no longer be considered a tax
They will make the decision during the next term.
I don't think that GJOpen has enough chutzpah to call this question 10 months in advance, so I'm adding uncertainty.

A penalty of a certain specified amount being changed to another certain specified amount ($0) should not interfere with the underlying law as written. However, it most certainly changes the ability of the system to sustain itself financially and provide healthcare for millions without access to it. Doing away with the Individual mandate to purchase basic healthcare has skyrocketed monthly and out of pocket care costs for those who could afford to purchase it prior to the penalty amount changing to zero. (I can cite multiple examples of people paying $500 monthly for ACA marketplace plans before penalty of $0 whose monthly payments jumped to $1500 after penalty changed to $0 and then had to give up needed healthcare). This is not to discount the argument that people are being forced to sign up for services that they donâ€™t want or need. However, I have seen firsthand dozens of individuals who were unhappy to have to purchase insurance only to be pleased with the overall outcome (being able to get a basic physical, labs, and health screenings w/o insurmountable fees and then having access to quality care near home for chronic conditions - in those who could not afford to adequately address health concerns before). During a worldwide pandemic, the multiple problems with our healthcare system have been well highlighted. No system is perfect, but I am currently banking on the fact that overall, no one wants to disrupt the system further at the present time when it is already highly chaotic and unorganized. And no alternative plan in place or even far along in the planning process for healthcare. But there remains a chance given the ages of some current sitting Supreme Court Justices and the possibility of another strict conservative justice being appointed before a decision is made. (Hang in there RBG!!!)
Re-affirming my forecast, albeit with a lack of research ... slight lean towards this being more likely than not.
A tax is a tax because SCOTUS already said so..even though it's temporarily set at 0.

The question is the constitutionality of the individual mandate. This question arose once Congress set the penalty to $0 in 2017. Recall that in NFIB vs Sebillus scotus said the mandate was a tax b/c it raised revenue, and it was not coercive b/c it was a small amount (said the CJ with a six figured salary and a really big house). So if the mandate-tax is now not revenue producing is it still a tax? Maybe it is an ineffective attempt at coercion but still a coercive (and corrosive) attempt to force a consumer to enter a market which is unconstitutional. It is red meat to the conservative justices. They can declare the mandate is no longer a tax and stand on principle and effect nothing. I do not think stare decisis will stay the hand of the conservative justices.
Roberts is unlikely to kill health care and with it the Supreme Court as we know it.

One week after the election, the justices will hear the two consolidated ACA cases, which ask whether the lawâ€™s individual insurance mandate is unconstitutional without a tax penalty and, if so, whether the rest of the law can remain standing." SCOTUSblog I don't see such an aggressive decision happening with all its chaotic dominoes falling towards the states. I also believe there will be a different POTUS next year but not sure yet how that may impact how the Court views this case. As to severability, not sure that will matter as constitutionality is the threshold question.
I admire @erikbays 's well-reasoned decisiveness but I remain gunshy. I agree with his arguments conceptually but I have been wrong about too many supreme court cases to go all in.
Down 15% to be at the consensus.

If Congress can set the amount of the penalty, they can set it anywhere they like, including zero. The CJ will want to keep the Court away from this issue at least until after the election. (He would deny this if asked, but one of the rules is you don't ask.)
Up 20%. It helps if I pay attention to the date. It is next session (of course) to be heard on 10 Nov.
Dipping my toe in the water here.

No one is contesting this issue. Even the Federal defendants agree that the individual mandate is now unconstitutional. See the Politico link in the question text. It is very rare for the court to take a position not argued by either side. The real issue being debated in the court is whether the individual mandate is severable, in other words, does this invalidate the entire Affordable Care Act or just the individual mandate. And that's not the issue being posed by this question. This question is addressing something no one is contesting.
The court will find a way to not answer the question.

I think the Supreme Court will go with the previously established precedent that the mandate is constitutional. While I have not read the law, presumably, the penalty amount could be reinstated at any rate at any time just as the rate was lowered to zero. Even if the penalty was originally meant to help fund the health care system, a new source for funding can always be legislated by Congress. If none of the other language in the law has changed, why would changing the rate render it unconstitutional?
(initial forecast) Likely to be like BvG & Cit U whichever way SCOTUS decides.
